conclusion: Plan to analyze the velocity-time graph to determine the distance fallen during the 10 to 15 seconds interval.

The image shows a velocity-time graph with time on the x-axis and velocity on the y-axis. The graph has a section where velocity increases from 0 to 20 m/s, then decreases from 20 m/s to 0 m/s. The 10 to 15 seconds interval is marked.
To find the distance, calculate the area under the velocity-time curve for the 10 to 15 seconds interval.
Identify the velocity at 10 seconds (20 m/s) and at 15 seconds (0 m/s) from the graph.
Calculate the area under the curve from 10 to 15 seconds, representing the distance fallen.
Approximate the area under the curve as a trapezoid and use the formula: Area = 1/2 * (a + b) * h.
Substitute values into the formula: Area = 1/2 * (20 + 0) * 5 = 50 meters.
Compare the calculated distance (50 meters) with 75 meters. Since 50 meters is less than 75 meters, conclude the distance fallen is less than 75 meters.
The distance fallen during the 10 to 15 seconds interval is less than 75 meters.
